name: Agra
fun_fact: Fun fact: Agra is home to petha, a translucent sweet made from crystallized winter melon that has been the city's signature dessert for over 350 years. The city also invented bedai-jalebi, the breakfast that locals say defines Agra like chole bhature defines Delhi.

hero_dishes.name: Bedai and Jalebi
hero_dishes.description: Agra's iconic breakfast combo: bedai (kachori made of black lentils and spices) served with spicy potato curry and curd, followed by sweet, crispy jalebi to offset the heat
hero_dishes.origin_story: Deviram Sweets claims to be the first to introduce bedai to Agra 75+ years ago. This breakfast is what chole bhature is to Delhiâ€”a defining local staple eaten from 9am-2pm daily
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Deviram Sweets (Pratap Pura crossing) - the oldest and most famous spot, serving masses on the street corner since the 1940s for just INR 30 for two

hero_dishes.name: Mughlai Nihari
hero_dishes.description: Slow-cooked beef or mutton stew with aromatic spices, traditionally eaten for breakfast by Agra locals
hero_dishes.origin_story: A royal Mughal dish passed down through generations, reflecting Agra's heritage as the seat of Mughal emperors who built the Taj Mahal
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Peshawri at ITC Mughal for fine dining; Daawat-e-Nawab for royal feast experiences

hero_dishes.name: Petha
hero_dishes.description: Translucent, chewy sweet made from crystallized ash gourd (winter melon), available in dry/hard or soft varieties with flavors like rose, paan, kesar, and angoori
hero_dishes.origin_story: Agra's signature sweet for 350+ years. Angoori petha is the most famous variety, named for its grape-like small cubes
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Panchhi Petha - the most famous petha shop in Agra, known for impeccable quality and wide variety of innovative flavors

hero_dishes.name: Kakori Kebab
hero_dishes.description: Minced lamb meat mixed with spices and cooked over charcoal fire, so tender it melts in the mouth
hero_dishes.origin_story: A famed Mughlai dish consumed by ancient royals, representing the pinnacle of royal cuisine. Agra's kebab tradition includes seekh, boti, and the prized galouti kebabs
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Jahanpanah near the Taj Mahal for traditional recipes; Pinch of Spice for excellent Mughlai dishes

signature_drinks.name: Tandoori Chai
signature_drinks.description: Smoky tea served in a hot clay cup that's been fired in a tandoor oven, creating a unique earthy flavor
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A visual and taste treat at street stalls throughout Agra, especially in Sadar Bazaar. The clay cup adds a distinctive smoky flavor locals crave

food_culture_notes: Chat Gali (Khao Gali) in Sadar Bazaar is an entire alley dedicated to street food - dahi bhallas, pav bhaji, gol gappe, crispy cheelas, and even Indianised Chinese and Italian
Locals crowd the streets of Sadar Bazaar, Raja Ki Mandi, and Kinari Bazaar for authentic chaat: aloo tikki, pani puri, papri chaat, samosa, kachori, and dalmoth (spicy lentil mix)
Biryanis follow traditional Lucknowi style with fragrant basmati rice layered with marinated meats, slow-cooked using the dum method
Keema naan (filled with spicy minced lamb or chicken) paired with chicken korma reflects Agra's Mughal heritage
For vegetarian options, locals go to Lakshmi Vilas (one of Agra's oldest restaurants for pure South Indian cuisine) or Joney's Place near Taj Ganj for malai kofta

landmarks: Street food stalls in Sadar Bazaar
